3.10pm BST

Closing summary

So here is a quick 3.10 summary.

European Union finance ministers are meeting in Vilnius, where they are discussing financial stability. The question of more finance for Greece is not on the official agenda, but it is clearly on the mind of Germany's finance minister. Earlier today the group agreed to write out the next cheque in Cyprus's bailout programme. Meanwhile data showed that employment in the eurozone fell slightly.

In the UK we had better than expected data on construction that have raised hopes for a boost to GDP numbers in the third quarter; while in the US disappointing data on retail sales has not snuffed out expectations that the Fed will start to taper its financial stimulus programme.

With that, I am signing off for the day.

Thank you for reading and for all your comments. Have a good weekend.

Updated at 3.10pm BST

2.55pm BST

Lehman: five years on

It is five years ago this weekend since Lehman Brothers collapsed. As the Guardian's Larry Elliott and Jill Treanor have written in today's paper, this triggered a lost decade for living standards, but it could have been worse.

In an interview with the Guardian former chancellor Alistair Darling recalled the moment when the chairman of the Royal Bank of Scotland Sir Tom McKillop told him they would run out of cash in hours with government help.

Here was the chairman of one of the world's biggest banks, who had shown disdain for politicians, asking us what we were going to do about it.

It sent a shiver down my spine. I knew from what had happened to Northern Rock a year earlier what could happen. And this was a massive bank. It would have been a catastrophe had RBS collapsed.

I am often asked which of my 1,000 days as chancellor was the worst. I am very spoiled for choice, but that was it. We were on the brink of a complete collapse of the world's financial system. RBS would have taken the rest of them down.

Read the full story: Lehman Brothers collapse, five years on: 'We had almost no control'

2.40pm BST

Cyprus gets its bailout cheque

Eurozone finance ministers approved the writing of another €1.5bn cheque to Cyprus earlier today, the second payment to the island under the rescue programme agreed earlier this year.

Cyprus has to stick to the rescue plan, was the message.

Because the short-run economic outlook remains difficult and subject to considerable uncertainty, continued full and timely policy implementation remains essential for the success of the programme.

Read the full text of the eurogroup statement here.

2.28pm BST

Retail sales: reaction

With data showing that US retail sales grew at just 0.2% in August, attention has gone straight back to the US Federal Reserve and its stimulus plans.

Chris Williamson at Markit Economics agrees that the Fed is on course to start "a small but symbolic" reduction in its asset purchases next week.


Although weaker than expected, the retail data are unlikely to stop the Fed starting to withdraw its stimulus at next week’s FOMC meeting. However, the Fed is most likely to make only a small but symbolic reduction to the stimulus programme, perhaps reducing the asset purchases by $5bn per month, due to the fragility of the upturn. Importantly, any tapering is likely to be accompanied by a statement of reassurance that any further tightening of policy will be carefully considered to ensure it does not set the recovery back.

2.15pm BST

Taper-snaper

After all the jumpiness about the Fed cutting its stimulus programme, investors now don't seem especially bothered, according to a Bloomberg poll.

Just under one third of those surveyed expect markets to fall if the Fed cuts its $85 bn per month bond buying programme, while 8% expect a rally. But 57% don't expect any sudden changes, because they are already expecting a taper.

So, the taper is nothing to worry about, because the taper is inevitable, or "priced in", as market watchers have it. Confused?

2.07pm BST

US sales data weaker than expected

US retail sales disappointed expectations, growing at just 0.2% below forecasts of 0.4%.

Retail sales were still up for the fifth month in a row, but the slowdown is expected to temper speculation that the Fed will cut its massive bond-buying programme.

1.44pm BST

India's growth forecast cut

India's economy is expected to grow more slowly this year, according to the prime minister's economic advisory panel.

The economists are forecasting growth of 5.3% for 2013, sharply down on their earlier estimate of 6.4%.

The opening sentence of the report gets straight to the point.

The performance of the economy over the past two years has been disappointing.

Domestic factors are to blame, they say, as India's economy had largely bounced back from the global crisis. The first problem was the "overstaying of financial stimulus measures. then India was hit by the worst monsoons in 28 years that led to a surge in cereal prices, feeding inflation into the economy.

On my very cursory reading, there does not appear to be much attention to the massive corruption scandals that could derail India's economic growth.

12.16pm BST

From the frontline of the Eurogroup press conference:

12.12pm BST

Lehman collapse "not an act of God" - Rehn

Olli Rehn also spoke about the collapse of Lehman Brothers on the 5th anniversary of its bankruptcy.

The financial crisis was not an act of God

Regulation and supervision had been significantly strengthened, he said.

We must never lower our guard, he said. Policymakers in national capitals and the IMF must remain vigilant, so the experience of 2008 "remains where it belongs - in the history books".

12.06pm BST

Eurozone crisis not over - Rehn

Olli Rehn, the EU commissioner for monetary affairs, has said it would be premature to say the eurozone crisis is over.

Speaking after a meeting of eurozone finance ministers, he said:

The summer has brought encouraging signs that the european economy has reached a turning point.

A gradual economic recovery is taking root in Europe.

The Q2 GDP figures were better than expected, although in line with the Commission's forecasts, he said. But he said complacency was "a key risk".

This is no time for shouting that the crisis is over.

Unemployment remains at dramatic levels in some countries in Southern Europe and that is why it is essential to step up economic reform in those countries.

11.59am BST

Eurogroup press conference

You can watch the press conference of the eurozone finance ministers here.

Updated at 12.05pm BST

11.48am BST

No easing of Portugal's budget deficit plans - eurozone leader

Portugal has got to stick to its austerity diet - that is the message from eurozone chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem.

On Wednesday, Portugal's deputy prime minister Paulo Portas argued that the budget deficit goal set for next year should be softened to 4.5 % of GDP rather than the agreed 4%.

This won't wash with Dijsselbloem, the Dutch finance minister, who leads the eurozone group of ministers.

I think it's important to stick to what we've now agreed within the programme, also including the deficit targets.

I don't think it's a good signal to keep the discussion alive whether the targets should be more or less.

The outside world should understand that Portugal and the Portuguese government is committed to what has to be done, what has been agreed. That will help towards an exit from the programme as soon as possible.

Not everyone is impressed with this argument, especially as the Netherlands was recently granted an extra year to meet its budget deficit target of 3% of GDP.

Updated at 11.49am BST

11.29am BST

Spanish debt at record levels

More pain in Spain, as it emerges that debt has risen to a record high. The Bank of Spain announced today that debt now stands at 92.2 % of the country's output, some way above the government's year-end target of 91.4 % of GDP

Spain's debt has doubled since the crash of 2008 and the International Monetary Fund expects it to top 100% by 2015.

Spotted by BabyBoomer55 

Updated at 11.38am BST

11.08am BST

Eurozone employment still shrinking

The number of people in work in the euro area fell by 0.1% in the second quarter of this year, according to data from Eurostat.

In the world of economists, this counts as good news, because the speed of shrinkage has levelled off. Eurozone employment was down 0.4% in Q1.

But even this faint glimmer of good news has not reached the stricken economies of southern Europe. Employment in Cyprus was down 2.1% in Q2, Spain recorded a 0.5% fall and Italy 0.3%. Greece eked out 0.1% growth in employment.

Nothing to celebrate, writes the EU commissioner for employment.

Updated at 11.09am BST

10.45am BST

Steinbrück's mega gaffe

Is this Germany's new chancellor?

Incredibly, with just over a week to go until Germany's elections, Angela Merkel's main rival to become German chancellor, Peer Steinbrück, has posed for this photograph.

Steinbruck thought it would be a good idea to publish the image - as Michael Steen at the FT's Frankfurt bureau explains:

According to the newspaper, Mr Steinbrück’s spokesman immediately intervened to say the photo would not be approved for publication. (In Germany, amazingly, public figures have the right to prevent publication of interviews by refusing to sign off on the text. In this case that might have extended to the photographs.) But Mr Steinbrück overruled his PR man and said the photo was fine.

Unsurprisingly, this has caused a storm in Germany.

Philipp Rösler, the economy minister and member of the Free Democrats, Merkel's junior coalition allies, said it was just not on.

This gesture is unacceptable for a chancellor candidate.

As one Twitter user wrote:

Unbelievable! It's not a fake! I can't imagine a chancellor like that.

Via AFP

Meanwhile, the Economist has backed Angela Merkel as the right person to lead Germany and Europe. 

We disagreed with Angela Merkel’s needlessly austere medicine: the continent’s recession has been unnecessarily long and brutal as a result. We wanted the chancellor to shrug off her cautious incrementalism and the mantle of her country’s history—and to lead Europe more forcefully.

And yet we believe Mrs Merkel is the right person to lead her country and thus Europe. That is partly because of what she is: the world’s most politically gifted democrat and a far safer bet than her leftist opponents. It is also partly because of what we believe she could still become—the great leader Germany and Europe so desperately needs.

10.18am BST

"Robin Hood" tax not dead yet - Germany

Straight from Vilnius - the Financial Transaction Tax, or Robin Hood tax, is not dead yet, says Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble, according to the Wall Street Journal's reporter on the spot.

Germany, along with France, has been a fan of the tax, which is designed to discourage speculation, but doubts about the plan's viability surfaced earlier this week after EU lawyers questioned the legality of the proposals. Catch up here.

10.09am BST

Construction data good news for economy : reaction

The recovery is building. That, at least, is the view of economists to ONS data showing that the UK construction industry grew by 2.2% in July.

Jeremy Cook, chief economist at World First, said the data would bolster hopes of improved growth figures for Q3.

Construction has probably been the most vulnerable of the main three sectors (alongside manufacturing and services) but today’s number will reinforce the belief that Q3 GDP is currently on track to outshine Q2’s 0.7%.

 Both public and private sector works have increased and alongside the increase in sentiment around the housing market, we should see the second half of the year remain a good one for the nation’s homebuilders.

Whether these increases will translate into a housing bubble will remain to be seen. We are not seeing dramatically irrational behaviour in housing yet, but a continuation of these increases will lead to an increasing froth around housing markets.

Alan Clark at Scotiabank reminds us that construction is a small, but volatile component of GDP, and can affect growth significantly.

UK construction output posted a punchy 2.2% m/m rise in July – a good start to the third quarter of the year.

 So it is so far so good for Q3 GDP. The key thing that we are waiting for is the monthly services output data. The CIPS services survey has gone up like a rocket of late, so we should be on track for the hard services data to perform well.

Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight thinks housebuilding activity could help constrain a new housing market bubble.

It is particularly encouraging that the improvement in construction activity is becoming broadly-based across sectors. Housebuilding activity is seeing particular improvement which is welcome news given concerns that a shortage of properties risks contributing to a new housing market bubble.

 The construction sector really does now seem to be establishing recovery following extended, deep weakness... It currently appears that housing market activity is really stepping up a gear, while thegovernment’s Help to Buy initiatives in the budget to boost housing market activity was particularly welcome news for housebuilders.

9.49am BST

UK construction industry growing

More signs that the UK housing market has roared back to life, with data showing that the UK construction sector grew 2.2% in July, compared to June.

The data from the Office for National Statistics showed that the sector was up 2% in July compared to the year before.

Updated at 9.49am BST

9.43am BST

Larry Summers tipped for Fed

The dollar has risen on speculation that former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers will be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve.

Traders are paying attention to a report in Japanese business daily Nikkei, which said that the White House was expected to announce Summers as early as next week, after the Fed's policy meeting on 17-18 September.

Observers have cautioned that Nikkei might have it wrong. As one trader told Reuters:

You have to wonder just how credible it is. I mean it would be understandable if the New York Times or the Wall Street Journal were reporting this.

But the market seems to be showing some reaction to this.

Summers will be a controversial choice. As Moira Herbst wrote on Comment is Free last month, his record on the economic crisis should rule him out.

A paid consultant to Citigroup, hedge fund DE Shaw and other companies, he is immersed in Wall Street both personally and professionally, posing the question of how he can possibly be trusted to regulate banks.

8.50am BST

#ipo

From the paper, here is our story on Twitter's plan to float on the stock market.

Naturally the social media company announced the plan on Twitter.

Now the big question is how to value the company, with estimates starting at $9 billion. Twitter will also be under pressure to show it can make money.

As Roger Kay, founder of Endpoint Technologies Associates, points out, any move to into advertising brings risks

If they start to put ads in, it's going to change the user experience. They haven't educated their users to accept the presence of ads.

Updated at 8.53am BST

8.30am BST

Greece: a 3rd bailout?

One of the most pressing topics for the eurozone is not on the official agenda at Vilnius: further help for Greece.

But the German finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble has told journalists Greece's current financing will be up for discussion today, although his Dutch counterpart Jeroen Dijsselbloem says it isn't.

Andrus Ansip, the prime minister of Estonia, a country that has been through a massive austerity drive, has said bailout fatigue is easing.

After Estonia joined the eurozone in 2011, many Estonians wondered why they should put €2 billion into the bailout pot.
But Ansip told Reuters in an interview that "bailout fatigue" was "not a hot topic in our country".

We have to understand that we are not just helping Greece or other countries, we are also protecting ourselves.

So we are creating those firewalls, and when those firewalls are high enough then we don’t have to spend so much money on fire extinguishers and most likely we will not get fire in our house. So we have to go on, we have to be flexible.

Updated at 8.53am BST

8.15am BST

Eurozone meeting: agenda

Here is a rundown of the agenda for the eurozone finance ministers’ meeting

9.45- 1pm* - eurozone ministers meet

1.30-3.30 - working lunch on banking union for all 28 European Union finance ministers

4.30-6.30 - more talks on financial stability; improving access to finance for SMEs, and the response to G20 summit, plus preparation for another G20 event.

*Local time, GMT+2

The Lithuanian government, chair of the meeting (because they hold the EU’s rotating presidency) has prepared a backgrounder, where they hail economic reforms by EU member states, but warn unemployment is “unacceptably high”.

Government deficits and current account deficits are decreasing, economic confidence is
stabilizing, while international competitiveness indicators show strong positive signs.
However, many challenging factors remain: in a number of member states the general
government debt level increased over the last year, unemployment persists at an
unacceptably high level and youth unemployment, in particular, remains a challenge for most
of the EU Member States.

The meeting continues on Saturday, with tax fraud on the ministers' agenda.

Updated at 8.53am BST

7.59am BST

Good morning

Welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

Greece’s bailout is expected to be back on the agenda again, as a meeting of eurozone finance ministers gets under way in Vilnius this morning. International lenders reckon Greece will need €10-11bn from the second half of 2014, but bailout fatigue is setting in. Other EU finance ministers (ie non eurozone countries) will join the meeting this afternoon, with the topic of financial stability up for discussion.

In the UK, construction figures will be published this morning, which are expected to show a significant uptick in housebuilding. From the US we will be looking out for the latest retail sales data.

CMC Markets have called a flat opening on European markets this morning.

I’ll be following these stories throughout the day …

Updated at 8.31am BST

webTitle: Forget house price caps – it's time for a tax on property gains | Phillip Inman

fields.standfirst: We need a brake on the investment bloodlust that overtakes buyers and sellers when house price inflation gets going
fields.body:
Surveyors are a bit cheeky when they call on the Bank of England to put the brakes on the housing market. In effect, they are saying they want all the pressure in the housing market – the pressure that creates a bubble – to stay in place and the central bank to act as a counterweight, upsetting everyone who wants to gamble on rising prices.

The Bank, in its role as chief City regulator, should act as a counterweight, but it could do with a little help in its job. Former governor Mervyn King insisted he would be prepared to take away the punch bowl just as the property party was getting in full swing. And Mark Carney, his successor, says the same. The trouble is that no one has ever had the bottle in the past. In full flow, the property market is worse than the stock market for departing from reality.

Simon Rubinsohn, chief economist at the surveyors' body Rics, says it is not in the interest of surveyors, or even those surveyors who act as estate agents, for the British obsession with property to create more booms and busts. Yet his industry simply will not consider the single biggest brake on the investment bloodlust that overtakes so many buyers and sellers when house price inflation gets going and that is a tax on property gains.

We must force people to rethink how they invest and steer them away from property. It channels a huge amount of spare capital and intellectual effort into something that is mostly unproductive.

Of course we need decent homes to live in and offices that aid productivity. But that is not what a property boom is about. It is about persuading the next generation of buyers to pay inflated prices in the expectation they will become super-creditworthy borrowers. A super-creditworthy borrower can live beyond their means by extracting value from their property asset.

A tax on land, subsuming council tax, would force us all to pay a little of the inflationary gain each year from rising land prices in the form of a tax. In most land tax schemes, the money is used to reduce income tax and transaction taxes like stamp duty. This means the only losers would be those people who rely on rental income and rising prices for their standard of living.

The Liberal Democrats will debate a mansion tax on £2m homes at their conference next week. It raises the prospect of further property taxes on a section of the market that largely escapes under the current council tax rules, yet it is only a tentative step.

A land tax promotes many good things. To limit property inflation we would all be in favour of new building. It would also encourage investment in more productive assets, like start-up companies, manufacturing businesses and export-led services firms. Right now, the re-balancing we so urgently need is being pushed off track as we again become suckered by the easy riches to be gained from joining the property pyramid scheme at an early stage.

We know people who wake up late to the potential gains will buy just as the pyramid collapses and be left with negative equity, but that's caveat emptor for you. We are supposed to understand property buying and selling, so buyer beware applies. Yet we forget past mistakes, as the economist Hyman Minsky famously posited.

"A fundamental characteristic of our economy is that the financial system swings between robustness and fragility and these swings are an integral part of the process that generates business cycles," he said. People are momentum investors by nature, not value investors. A Minsky moment depicts a crash that follows a long period of prosperity driven by rising asset values.

He said only government intervention can override the cycle, which is repeated because participants in the system forget about past crashes (because they are always in a new paradigm).

There is much more to say about land value taxes and their knock-on effects, positive and negative, and who wins and loses. Suffice it to say, the prospect of another house price bubble should spur a debate not only about regulation, but how a shift in the tax system could strip away, or at least temper, the motivation to turn a home into a pension or the cash needed to buy a car while incomes remain static.

webTitle: Songbird Estates flies high despite Walkie Talkie and Shell problems

fields.standfirst: Company faces multi-million pound bill to fix skyscraper and pay for delays to Shell headquarters development
fields.body:
Songbird Estates faces a multi-million pound bill for two recent setbacks, including the recent car-melting skyscraper.

The property group reported a 6% rise in half year net assets per share, but told Reuters its Canary Wharf subsidiary would pay a sum in the "low single digits" to fix the Walkie Talkie building in the City of London. Rechristened the Walkie Scorchie, the building's concave structure reflected sunlight to such an extent the heat melted parts of a car, a bicycle and was also used to fry an egg.

Songbird also faces a £1m to £2m bill for a delay to its proposed development of Royal Dutch Shell's headquarters in London, after the government said it would review planning approval given by local authorities.

The problems have not undermined Songbird's shares, which have flown 4.75p higher to 156p. Peel Hunt said:

Songbird reports very strong first half net asset value growth driven by a portfolio that is 100% London, 95% occupied, long-let (13 years to break) and well positioned for a recovery in the City lettings market. The corporate structure is far from ideal, but with the shares trading on a 34% discount – one of the largest in the sector – we retain our buy rating and increase our target price.

webTitle: Imagination Technologies climbs on Apple launch but Arm suffers from profit taking

fields.standfirst: Morgan Stanley issues upbeat note on Imagination, pointing to prospects with Apple and Broadcom
fields.body:
Apple shares may be in the doldrums after a disappointing iPhone launch, but one of its suppliers is moving higher.

Imagination Technologies has added 26.5p to 333.9p after Morgan Stanley issued an overweight rating on the chip designer. The bank said Imagination's shares had been hit by poor newsflow in the past six months, but now things seemed to be looking up:

Apple announced that the new iPhone5S would be compatible with OpenGL 3.0 and that the graphics performance would be much better – this points to Apple moving to Rogue which is the new generation GPU from Imagination.
Apple confirmed that the new iPhone 5C would run on A6 chip. We believe that some investors had been worried that the C version would have been designed with a single chip solution from a third party and thus without Imagination. Broadcom announced it would buy the LTE chip business of Renesas. Renesas LTE chip includes an apps processor with an Imagination GPU. Broadcom has never used Imagination before. This provides some upside risk to earnings next year, should Broadcom ramp at Samsung and others.

Meanwhile Imagination has also announced a new licensing agreement with Taiwanese semiconductor company MediaTek.

Rival chip designer Arm has slipped 5p to 981.5p on profit taking following recent gains.

Elsewhere ITV is 2.2p better at 181.8p after Nomura raised its price target from 170p to 200p, saying:

Continued UK macroeconomic improvement means we raise our ITV 2013 ad forecast to 1.5% (from 1%) and our 2014 forecast to 4% (from 2%).

webTitle: Mining groups lead FTSE 100 lower ahead of US Federal Reserve meeting

fields.standfirst: Investors cautious on expectation central bank could begin to ease its bond buying programme
fields.body:
Miners are leading the markets lower as investors await next week's US Federal Reserve meeting.

Ahead of US retail sales figures later in the day, markets are betting that the central bank could begin easing its bond buying programme, given recent reasonable economic data.

Gold is on course for its worst week for two months and copper is at a five week low, in the expectation that the Fed money taps will be turned off.

So Glencore Xstrata, boosted earlier in the week by higher than expected cost savings from its merger, is down 9.05p at 334.6p while Anglo American has lost 44p to 1576.5p. Indeed seven of the top ten fallers in the leading index are mining groups.

The FTSE 100 is currently down 22.72 points to 6566.26, amid continuing nervousness about Syria as diplomatic moves to resolve the crisis continue. Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, said:

Some risk [is] being taken off the table ahead of the Fed decision next week and reports from Asia of the more hawkish Larry Summers being chosen as the next Fed Chairman over current vice chairwoman and more accommodative Janet Yellen.
Asia equities were in the red with sentiment weighed down by the prospects of tapering replacing worries over Syria (although the situation is still uncertain).

Among the risers, IMI has been lifted 15p to £14.92 after analysts at Berenberg raised their target price on the industrial group from £13 to £14.20, following a reasonable half year performance from the business. But Berenberg kept its hold rating, saying:

The stock is now up 37% year to date and valuation looks rich even on 2014 estimates, but the ongoing share buyback and the sale of the merchandising business are likely provide support for the shares in the near term.

JD Wetherspoon has dipped 6p to 729p as the pubs group reported a 6.3% rise in annual profits but said it expected lower like-for-like sales because of higher costs and taxation.

webTitle: Lehman collapse: the liquidator's story

fields.standfirst: PricewaterhouseCoopers' Tony Lomas couldn't believe US authorities let Lehman fail, given the inevitable domino effect
fields.body:
In the five years since 7.56am on Monday 15 September 2008, when a judge put the UK arm of Lehman Brothers into administration, Tony Lomas has been unravelling the $1.1bn (£700m) of assets and liabilities inside the collapsed bank.

Even for this partner at the accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), who has unwound companies as diverse as the Maxwell empire and the British arm of collapsed energy group Enron, the sums involved that fateful and unforgettable Monday morning were eyewatering, even scary.

The 56-year-old restructuring expert had watched the minutes ticking on the clock awaiting the decision from the judge, knowing the London market would start trading at 8am and that mayhem could unfold. He did not want to contemplate what might happen "as soon as 8 o'clock came and the payments were due".

Even now, five years on, he admits he finds it hard to believe that the US authorities allowed Lehman Brothers to fail, causing the domino effect on its entities around the world. Sitting in his corner office high up on the 23rd floor in a Canary Wharf tower, Lomas recalls: "I was disbelieving that it could have been allowed to happen because I could see what would unfold would be immense."

Unlike many of the other administrations the industry veteran has worked on, Lomas had barely any warning that Lehman was heading for the wall. It was a Saturday night and he was having a Chinese meal with his family in his favourite Essex restaurant when he took a call from Elizabeth Lee, lead lawyer for Lehman in London, who had been advised to prepare for the possibility that that the Wall Street firm might go bust over the weekend. She told Lomas she needed him to make plans – completely in secret – in case a rescue operation for Lehman across the Atlantic failed. "I started to have confidential conversations with my relevant service line leaders. If we had to walk in on Monday morning, I needed an army," Lomas said.

But it was all about trust. "Lehman hadn't gone bust. I was only there in case it did," he said.

The events that unfolded that weekend have now gone down in history as some of the dramatic in the financial world. No one had expected Lehman Brothers to fail – the US authorities had orchestrated a takeover of another troubled firm Bear Stearns only six months earlier – and the decision by the US to refuse to rescue it led to fears about the stability of other banks.

Once the judge pulled the plug , Lomas needed to set about understanding the structure of the bank – formally known in the UK as Lehman Brothers International (Europe) – and finding out if he could pay the 5,500 staff based at the London headquarters of 25 Bank Street. He had to find the money to pay the staff, as £3bn of cash had been swept across the Atlantic on the Friday night to the parent company. With the parent bankrupt, the London arm had no money to pay it staff or make payments on any of its bills.

Lomas admits that the next 10 weeks were chaotic as his team tried to assemble a plan. Within the first days, 2,500 staff transferred to Japanese bank Nomura, which took on the equities business in Britain. By Christmas the headcount had fallen to 700 and shortly afterwards reached 500.

Now Lehman Brothers International (Europe) employs 500 staff – including frontline traders and back office lawyers – complemented by 200 or so from PwC, all under Lomas. He points out that the operation is still a bank, regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority.

"We've recruited. Many were previously here, others were not. We've gone out of our way to create a business-as-usual environment. We provide rewards, we pay market [rates]. We have a training programme, we have objective-setting and appraisals. There are bonus systems and promotion and disciplinary procedures. This is a business," Lomas says.

Five years ago, his concern had been about the risks of taking on a job that was so big and unprecedented. "I was thinking about the big risk for PwC. Would we be able to control the risk? The value would be eroded and we would be blamed and it would take a long term to control the situation. When stakeholders and customers of the bank are at risk of losing hundreds of millions or billions of pounds, situations can become very litigious and those are very scary numbers to be litigated," he said.

For the most part, the situation did not spiral out of control. Some hedge funds had money locked into Lehman, with shares in banks and other entities, and needed it back. Walking in the door of 25 Bank Street – now the offices of JP Morgan – Lomas said he drew upon plans his company had used (and are still using) to unravel the UK arm of Enron, which collapsed in 2001.

The experience led to his discussing with regulators ways to draw up contingency plans for banks in the future. Ideas like this have become known as living wills – though five years on from the crisis few are yet ready to be tested and Lomas gesticulates that such a plan could easily create a 2ft-high paper stack. If he had one for Lehman, it "might have removed 25% of the uncertainty and reduced the instability and the chaos, but people would still have panicked".

This month he intends to make another payment to creditors on top of £13.6bn already handed back and admits that the 10-year lease in the corner of Citigroup's tower in Canary Wharf will expire before the job is done. He will have retired – PwC requires partners to leave at 60 – but he can already see creditors in Lehman getting their money back, racking up fees of £1bn for PwC in the process.

"There is a reasonable chance now that we have enough money to pay the ordinary unsecured creditors in full. Then there is the shareholder claims. At that level of recovery, I've still got enough money. It is possible in due course that we will prove this company was balance-sheet solvent. It didn't fail the balance-sheet test. What it failed was the cashflow test – it couldn't pay its debts when they fell due."

webTitle: Lehman collapse: learning the lessons

fields.standfirst: Former Lehman Brothers vice-president Larry McDonald was as shocked as many of his colleagues at the cataclysm
fields.body:
Larry McDonald was living just a few blocks from Lehman Brothers' Manhattan headquarters when he discovered that his former employee was one bank that wasn't too big to fail.

Now a bestselling author, the former Lehman vice-president advises hedge funds, pensions and others on risk using the lessons he learned at the bank. But five years ago he was as shocked as many of his colleagues at the cataclysm. "A group of us had left in the spring and summer before the collapse, worried about what was going on there. But I had millions of dollars in restricted stock that I couldn't sell," said McDonald.

His mobile phone died several times that September weekend, drained by a battery of calls from worried colleagues. He had heard rumours that the bankers and regulators looking at Lehman were considering letting it fail.

Stifling any urge to delight in McKillop's predicament, the chancellor said the government would shortly announce details of a rescue plan for UK banks caught up in the backwash from the collapse of Lehman, little more than three weeks earlier. For Darling, this was the stuff of nightmares. It wasn't simply that cash machines would stop working and cheques would no longer be cashed, although that was perceived by the Treasury and the Bank of England as a clear risk. It was the knowledge that the meltdown of a bank the size of RBS would send shockwaves through an already weakened global financial sector and bring other institutions down with it. "It sent a shiver down my spine. I knew from what had happened to Northern Rock a year earlier what could happen. And this was a massive bank. It would have been a catastrophe had RBS collapsed," he said. "I am often asked which of my 1,000 days as chancellor was the worst. I am very spoiled for choice, but that was it. What could have gone down in history as Black Tuesday dawned with the chancellor flying out for talks with fellow finance ministers. Although it was less visible than the queueing outside branches of Northern Rock a year earlier, the prolonged unwillingness of banks to lend to each other threatened to be far more damaging. Lord Myners, brought in by Gordon Brown as City minister after the Lehman collapse, said he was shocked when shown official figures showing how inter-bank lending had dried up. "This was the real bank run," Myners said. "You think of the senior citizens outside Northern Rock branches, but the real run was the one that took place in October, when really substantial depositors were willing to pay penalties to move their deposits. Deposits were not being renewed. "There was a waterfall chart. You could see the proportion of deposits that was not being renewed – hence the need to do something – which had an element of shock and awe about it." For those running Britain's banks, the change in the climate was sudden and, for their institutions, potentially fatal. In the good years, banks had become highly leveraged – they had increased their lending far more rapidly than they had built up capital to guard against losses. With markets booming, the banks' supposedly failsafe models showed that catastrophic losses were out of the question. In any event, they could always rely on the wholesale money markets – populated by other financial institutions – to see them through any cash-flow problems. These beliefs were shattered in the weeks that followed the Lehman collapse. None of the executives at RBS or HBOS, the two most prominent casualties of the crisis, would talk to the Guardian for this series but it was clear from the testimony of Andy Hornby, HBOS's chief executive, and Lord Stevenson, its chairman, to parliamentary committees that they were completely flummoxed – and terrified – when they found that the wholesale markets were closed for business. Lord Turner, who took over as chairman of the Financial Services Authority a week after the American authorities failed to find a buyer for Lehman, believes the crisis pre-dated the collapse of Lehman, and even the run on Northern Rock in September 2007. "For me the lesson learnt is that the roots of this crisis go back very deep. Over a number of decades we allowed too much leverage to grow in the real economy, and we allowed the banking system to become over-leveraged. I think we were running a system with such small buffers of capital and liquidity that by 2006-07 a crisis was bound to occur. "You can go back and ask, had something been done differently in 2007 might the precise path of the crisis been different: but that's not the key point. "We created an over-leveraged financial system and an over-leveraged real economy.
